item.title: The Bobiverse Series by Dennis E. Taylor
item.description: The Bobiverse follows the exploits of Bob, a computer engineer who lives the dream by becoming fantastically wealthy only to die shortly after and awake after his consciousness has been uploaded into a computer which is going to be use to control a von Neumann probe (a self-replicating spacecraft). The series follows Bob as he expands through the universe, saves humanity and a few other species from existential threats, and ponders the meaning of the universe.

item.title: The Three-Body Problem Series by Cixin Liu
item.description: One of my work friends had recommended The Three-Body Problem to me and it sounded interesting â€” it starts with the Chinese cultural revolution and goes through the heat death of the universe. You know, usual stuff there. The original is written in Chinese and while I found that the story was great sometimes the prose was a little lacking. I’m not sure if that’s due to the translation, language and cultural differences in writing between English and Chinese, or if the Cixin Liu’s style just isn’t quite what I was used to coming off of reading a lot of Scalzi

item.title: What Books I'm Reading
item.description: #2022 Thinking in Systems Donella H. Meadows Why We’re Polarized Ezra Klein You’re Never Weird on the Internet (Almost) Felicia Day The End of Everything (Astrophysically Speaking) Katie Mack Old Man’s War Series _John Scalzi_ Old Man’s War was John Scalzi’s debut novel and it is fantastic.
